so this is a session about uh enterprise Android and specifically about the things that Motorola is doing to add
features to Android to make it better suited for enterprise use And my name is
Rick Rogers I'm the product manager for a program at Motorola called MX
And uh MX is uh uh an ongoing program that is uh designed to add features to
Android uh features that uh because of our experience of working with enterprise customers we know that
enterprise operating systems need and uh for various reasons uh aren't there in
Android Android of course is is a great operating system and and designed to be a consumer operating system Uh Google's
spent a lot of money to to create the uh uh the code and make it available to to
all of us which is great but they're focused on uh the devices that uh uh
best suit their their business model which are consumer devices which are used generally by a single user u
managed by that user So the user sort of has complete control over what's going on on the device And uh as we'll see as
we go through the presentation uh some of those features are uh not that suitable for for use in the enterprise
So we're uh we're working to uh adapt Android so it fits better with the enterprise And uh as I said I'm the
product manager for this MX program but I should also point out too that um uh you shouldn't get the impression that
we're now focused on Android or something to the exclusion of Microsoft Microsoft is still a very strong partner
uh with uh Motorola and in fact I was in meetings this morning with with them about the future directions that we're
taking with them So uh you should see uh a balance of products coming uh in the
future from Motorola uh some based on Android some based on Microsoft products
Uh and and as I say we're still strong partners Uh and the other thing I should point

our uh program to to enhance Android and it's an ongoing program uh we we started

aren't in Android uh today at least and uh things that we'd like to add over

an ongoing program that uh with no end in sight Um it was formerly called MESA
If any of you have heard of a program called Mesa at uh at Motorola uh we changed the name to MX Uh it's not

me as a product manager are my internal product development teams So we deliver these extensions to the product

Um for the few things that do require uh interfaces like barcode reading uh we

If you uh if you Google ET1 uh integrator guide uh it'll give you a
a URL a pointer to to that So I said we
were adding enterprise features So what are those enterprise features what what makes an enterprise device different from a consumer device and uh I'll build
some on this slide and then there's there are more on on the next slide that we'll talk about So this is uh in
general not specific to um to MX or to Android for that matter but they are
features that are included in that 150 page list of of things that we'd like to uh see in Android based enterprise
devices Battery management clearly that's that's a big issue for mobile devices and for enterprise devices uh in
particular So consumer devices consumers don't mind too much if they have to recharge their phone overnight right
they're they're sleeping anyway They can as long as they remember to plug in the phone and recharge it Uh it's not a big
deal In the enterprise it is a big deal because devices are often used over multiple shifts Um if a if a device
battery uh uh you know loses charge in the middle of a shift uh there should be
a way to swap the battery without losing the context of of uh the work that's
being done with the device Those kinds of issues that are different between enterprise and and consumer So we tend
to offer larger batteries uh the ability to swap batteries and and maintain context uh things like that
Wireless connectivity again for for a consumer uh wireless connectivity is fine if it connects with their home
wireless LAN and uh you know when they're in Starbucks or whatever connects with with that wireless land uh
they're satisfied with that and it meets their need but uh the enterprise has in general uh much more stringent
requirements around wireless connectivity uh including wireless sign extensions like CCX for Cisco
connectivity uh some Motorola extensions that that we've added additional E types
uh the ability to connect to 5 GHz which uh some consumer devices uh support but
in general where they do support it they support it poorly Um uh in and and you may or may not be
aware that uh for for many enterprises uh 5 GHz is a way for them to isolate
their enterprise traffic from wireless land that they might want to make available to customers or other uh
interfering uh sources of of uh uh traffic in in that band in that
2.4 GHz band um diversity switched antennas uh and
things like that that uh again make the wireless connectivity in the enterprise world more robust and are less important
in the consumer world tend to get sacrificed in the name of uh uh sleek
design and things like that So extra antennas tend to get tend to get thrown out of the design because they u they
work against the uh the sleekness of the design or whatever that uh people are looking for in the consumer
world Form factor stability and enterprise life cycle I I
uh trying to remember what were the three things that were mentioned in the the keynote yesterday security
manageability I think and life cycle were the three uh big differentiators that were pointed out there And and life
cycle certainly is consumer devices Again uh consumer OEMs tell us that they typically build a device for uh 6 to9
months and then they don't build it anymore So they sell off whatever is left after they they've built that many
But it's a fairly short uh uh manufacturing run when compared to the
kinds of uh offerings that we have in the enterprise world and that enterprise customers need Enterprise customers
typically need years of support for uh the devices that they buy from us They
also need um a better controlled uh uh maintenance
and and update path to the software on the device Right so again consumer
devices uh typically the carrier will push a new update uh to a device whenever it's convenient for the carrier
uh and the user has the option of accepting it now or later but you know it's it keeps bugging you till you do Um
enterprises for enterprises a software update can be a huge expense actually not only for the expense of of actually
updating the devices but the expense of proving their applications still work with that updated version of the
software things like that So enterprises need a more controlled uh ability to
update devices still get security patches and maintenance updates as as required but to have more control over
how those are delivered and uh when they're delivered to specific
devices Uh consumer devices also are obviously designed to to appeal to uh consumers So uh they have features uh
that uh consumers like like high fidelity sound and high resolution displays which
uh in in most cases don't have a a need
a a real use case for enterprise use and in some cases uh are a detriment to
enterprise use because they sacrifice battery life for more pixels or or higher fidelity sound Uh so
uh again an enterprise device where an enterprise device would not include those features consumer devices do
because they're more appealing for uh consumer kinds of usage models Uh also different touch and
display technologies I talked about resolution of the display but uh for the touchcreen itself as well Often in the
enterprise uh usage model the the user has gloves on so they can't use the capacitive display because the the
gloves won't allow that to work um or they're using it outdoors in the
rain and capacitive displays don't work that well in the rain So uh so you know
uh enterprise devices some enterprise devices need to have uh resistive uh touchcreens in order to uh accommodate
those usage models And of course um neither Google
nor Apple or any of the the consumer device manufacturers uh offer a roadmap
that uh an enterprise could depend on for what kind of devices will be available in the near future Um pretty
much from from uh Google or Apple you you find out about it when they uh announce it Uh and you know the devices
are are available uh immediately thereafter Uh so our customers require
more predictability in terms of what devices what device features are going to be available uh in the future and
what form factors those devices will have And finally the ability to
customize when those OEMs are making consumer devices over 6 to9 months they're making tens of millions of
devices and there's no business model there for making custom customizations
to those devices in smaller quantities it's just it doesn't fit their their manufacturing process and their whole
way of doing business Um but our enterprise customers often do need uh customizations to to the device So
that's one of the things we've integrated into our business model the ability to do that
Security was one of the other uh big three uh features that were uh highlighted in the in the keynote And uh
you know clearly there are uh requirements in the enterprise space sometimes legal requirements um uh
particularly around you know credit card information in the retail world or uh HIPPA u capability in in the healthcare world
uh and uh as well as you know mandated requirements like FIPS for government
users of devices uh for securing information and the ability to react to
situations say if the device is rooted or something like that so that uh data can be protected absolutely on the
device uh not so important for the consumer you know um uh it's important
to have your your contact information and and your email uh protected but it's not a legal requirement Nobody's going
to sue you if uh somebody gets a hold of your your contact information Improve productivity through
features like multi-user support the ability for multiple for several people to to use a single device uh to use it
you know over over a series of shifts perhaps and features like rapid application access where uh for for
applications that don't require a high level of security uh price check is is a
typical example you go to to Walmart right you can check the price on on uh an item by holding it up to a a kiosk
barcode scanner Uh it's important to be able to uh invoke applications outside
of a login So you don't have to log in to to use that price check scanner at Walmart And uh there are a whole class
of of applications where where that makes sense And it improves productivity by not having you know in an enterprise
again the the uh user might have 12 character password with you know a complex password and that takes a while
to enter on a mobile device on the virtual keyboard Uh so it's important to have that that kind of uh capability to
improve productivity Uh enterprise feature integration So I
said we're going to show uh the the demo code is about barcode scanning and uh
it's important to have these features integrated or integraable into the device So the ET1 with Snap-On
peripherals and things like that that integrate onto the device as opposed to having a a separate uh thing like a a
sled with a barcode reader and extended battery development support and uh
multiple run times development support clearly for the the features that we're adding uh there needs to be robust
development support that uh developers like yourselves can take advantage of of the features that are there Uh multiple
run times the ability to uh particularly to port legacy applications Uh many of
our customers have applications that they've built for other runtime environments So it's important to uh
enable the transition of those to to newer runtimes as they become available
durability and environmental is is probably what people think of first when they think of our devices They think of
ruggedized devices that you could drop on the concrete or uh take into a freezer or out into a desert and not
have to worry about uh the environmental uh effects Consumer devices uh obviously
are not made for that Um uh someone was telling me today that the the uh the upper temperature limit on an
iPhone is 95 degrees and uh Fahrenheit and uh uh the temperature in Dallas last
year I guess exceeded that for 101 days So so you know
um I don't know how many iPhone failures they had as a result but but uh but clearly extended temperature and uh
durability are uh key features for enterprise use uh device management not
only the uh normal device management that uh is is available on consumer
devices but uh more uh I almost said invasive but more comprehensive uh
device management because enterprise devices are owned by the enterprise They aren't owned by the user of the device
So the enterprise needs to have the capability to tightly manage that device lock down what they need to lock down on
the device and and own it voice and audio support Many of our customers uh
uh need to combine the ability to to compute with a mobile computing device uh with the ability to connect uh by
voice over over wireless LAN to uh other users uh using devices Uh so uh they
need to have that that uh local capability to do to do voice and not have to go out to the WAN
So any questions about consumer versus enterprise i said we had that 150 page
document and what we've done with it is take the features that are that are identified in that document and break
them down into these uh 11 different categories So uh just briefly to to walk
through what those categories are to give you an idea of the kinds of of things that we're looking at uh incorporating into Android uh MDMs Uh so
that's that device management uh aspect of uh being able to manage the device comprehensively Uh and that's not only
for Motorola's own uh MDM solution MSP but also for thirdparty uh MDMs Many of
our customers have standardized on a uh an MDM that's not MSP that they use
across all their mobile devices and they don't want to introduce you know another MDM to uh to manage uh Motorola devices
So uh we're working with those thirdparty MDM providers so that they can manage our Android devices as well
Security management we talked about the the kinds of security features that uh we see being added that need to be added
into uh consumer operating system like uh Android to make it suitable for the enterprise So those all all fit in there
Application management is all about um controlling what applications uh can run
on the device and that can be through it's currently through a white list Uh
so and we'll talk about the specific features that are implemented so far but essentially uh an administrator or an
MDM can establish a white list of applications for a user group and then
members of that user group can only install and run uh applications that are listed on that white list
Uh there are other approaches blacklisting grrey listing uh things like that Uh but but that's all part of
it And then uh also included in there is the ability to uh lock the device down
into uh what's typically referred to as kiosk mode where the device can only run
one application or a few applications from a restricted home screen So that you can restrict users so that they
don't get at the wireless LAN settings for example Uh and if they were to take the device uh it would be useless uh
because it can't connect to any SSID other than the one that it's already connected to Uh expense management uh to begin
with at least is is primarily oriented around telecom expense management So for wide area network devices based on
Android uh some of our customers um want devices that have uh multiple SIM
capability so that they can choose uh between carriers uh that that are available and the the plans the the the
uh contracts that they have with those carriers um uh can uh uh change the the
price that they pay for wireless connectivity based on time of day day of week all kinds of of different uh uh uh
policies So they want to be able to set policies that say you know on 7 o'clock
on Thursdays uh pick this SIM use that wide area connection those kinds of things
Performance management is mostly around taking advantage of the performance capabilities that uh can either be
accelerated for for uh via the hardware through the graphics accelerator or the
crypto accelerator or whatever accelerators are are available or through optimized software libraries And
uh Motorola has has a lot of that um uh intellectual property both hardware and
software acceleration capability uh through our our legacy businesses and uh
some of the other businesses besides uh enterprise that we're involved in
uh wireless management I I talked before about the need to add uh particularly wireless LAN capabilities that aren't uh

ability to to solidly connect to uh the wireless LAN and use it for He's

Supplemental hosted services uh where so think of the cloud things that are done

users to user groups and uh manage those user groups as a group without having to
manage individual users Uh I talked about whitelists before Um I mentioned blacklists and uh
grrey lists as uh things that we we've identified for the future Blacklist white list is you can run this
application if it's listed A blacklist is you cannot run this application if it's listed The problem with blacklists
is you can never be sure that you've got every application that you want to outlaw on the blacklist With a white
list you don't have that problem You're just listing the ones that you can you can absolutely run A gray list is as you
might expect something in between uh where a third-party rating agency rates
applications gives them a number by um how uh uh
usable non-dangerous they are if you will say say 1 to 10 and then uh through
the MDM or an administrator can set a value and say okay you can't install or
run any application that's not at least six on that list So it gives a gives
some mid midground uh flexibility to uh whitelisting and blacklisting Right now
we have whitelisting by user group secure storage with the uh again with
the the launch of ET1 we uh added volume file encryption to uh Android so that
you can create an encrypted uh file volume uh in in the flash and uh uh make
use of that store the key securely and all that kind of stuff That's the next one
Um and then uh as as you probably know with Ice Cream Sandwich Android has
added uh device encryption So uh we'll be carrying on both of those Some
customers want uh the full SD card for example encrypted Uh other customers
just want to be able to encrypt separate uh file systems separate partitions if you will and uh keep use separate keys
for the for those for for whatever reason So we'll we'll have both of those moving forward Unassisted device
management Again in the consumer world the user is is king Uh you always ask the consumer or the user if uh you want
to install something on the the device or uh if you want to make a settings change or or those kinds of things In
the enterprise world uh the user shouldn't have control Uh so we've
implemented things like unassisted device uh management where uh an MDM can
uh download and install application without uh the user even knowing that that they did it So the user isn't
presented with the normal you know do you approve these permissions or or those kind of things It just gets
installed Uh integrated barcode scanning Again we'll show more of that as we as we get into the demo
app So those are the kind of things we added to begin with

for MX And uh I said I'd talk a bit about GMS apps So Google mobile services I

Um Google for its its own commercial reasons uh requires OEMs if that in

Then when you buy an application from Google Play it gets charged to the credit card that's associated with uh that Gmail ID those kinds of things Um

Okay Okay We have 10 minutes left Great Um so I'll quickly walk through the
these uh example applications that demonstrate um how easy it is to incorporate barcodes into uh an
application for example And the application the demo that I chose was a price check application because that's a
common thing Everybody uh knows what that is You scan a barcode you you find out what the price is And I did a couple
of variants or conceived of a couple of variants Yes Uh the scanning is via the
camera or in this case it is There's also a an accessory barcode reader a
laser barcode reader that can be plugged into the device but in this case I'm using the camera
Um so the sort of vanilla version the original version was uh where you would
enter the the barcode uh information by hand and obviously enter the price by
hand as well and uh just use that as a as sort of the base version of of such
an application And it would accept anything as a a price code You know it wouldn't check to to know that it's a a
universal price code It's just a string of digits and uh look up the price and if it can't find it give you an error
message And so an enhanced version of that would be to actually use the camera as a barcode scanner on the device and
use that to enter the the uh universal price code And uh in this case I was
saying we would accept any barcode that it read as a UPC We wouldn't look at the type of barcode we would only you know
take a string that came out a data string that came out of any kind of a barcode whether it was UPC or QR or
anything else And then a third kind of variant of
the application oh I should say the second version of the application would be using uh a feature
that that we built into the ET1 uh key event injection though um the barcode
scanner looks like it's typing in the barcode information to your application
and it does that by injecting key events that look like somebody's pressing on the keys
Okay the third version of the application uses the intent that I talked about earlier that we have an
intent defined uh that uh the barcode reader can can issue and in addition to
